abstractText: A bone conduction (BC) sound presented on either side of the head will travel to the cochleae in both ears, and this crosstalk phenomenon is considered one factor limiting the benefits of binaural hearing with BC. Previous studies have demonstrated the feasibility of measuring the phase and level required for crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea; however, given a human subject’s inability to consistently detect low frequencies, this method is limited to cancellations at frequencies above 1000 Hz. This study describes an alternative approach for implementing a crosstalk cancellation system for low frequencies by measuring ear-canal sound pressure (ECSP). Since the ear canal is close to the cochlea, we hypothesized that altering ECSP in response to a BC stimulation may be used to achieve crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea. Our approach relies on ECSP measurements to estimate impulse responses (IRs) from bone transducers to a probe microphone in the ear canal. The IRs are then used to predict the phase and level required for crosstalk cancellation at the probe microphone’s location. To confirm the hypothesis, we measured tone reception threshold (TRT), the lowest tone level participants could detect, under two conditions: with and without crosstalk cancellation. Although crosstalk cancellation was designed to occur at the probe microphone and not at the cochlea, the TRT results showed that participants were still able to perceive cancellations at frequencies below 1000 Hz. INDEX TERMS bone conduction, bone transducer, crosstalk cancellation, probe microphone

INDEX TERMS bone conduction, bone transducer, crosstalk cancellation, probe microphone
I. INTRODUCTION
ASOUND transmitted to the cochlea through the bonesof the skull is known as bone conduction (BC) sound. Unlike an air conduction (AC) sound, a BC sound presented on either side of the head will travel to the cochleae in both ears, as illustrated in Fig. 1. This study refers to the BC sound that propagates to the ear on the opposite side of the head as a “crosstalk” sound.
Because a BC sound stimulates both cochleae, it has long been debated whether wearing a pair of BC hearing devices is beneficial to the ability to hear with both ears, especially for patients with bilateral conductive hearing loss (BCHL) [1]– [3]. To confirm that binaural benefits exist, speech-in-noise and localization tests were carried out on patients fitted with bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHAs) [4], [5] and on normalhearing participants with bone transducers (BTs) mounted on a headband [6]. It was reported that participants were able to
maintain accurate sound localization within 30o/45o [4]–[6]; however, this localization accuracy decreased as sounds were moved to the extreme right or left of the subjects [7]. For speech-in-noise tests where speech and noise originated from two different directions, the benefit of BC stimulation was approximately half the decibel level as that of AC stimulation [8]. Other research studies have also confirmed that the binaural benefits exist but are limited due to crosstalk [9], [10]. Therefore, crosstalk is considered a primary limiting factor of the benefits of binaural hearing with bone conduction.
There are five different pathways that allow a BC sound to stimulate the cochlea in the inner ear. These are (1) the softtissue vibration that produces the ear-canal sound pressure (ECSP) [11]–[13]; (2) the bone vibration that also produces the ECSP [14]; (3) the inertial movement on the middle ear ossicles [15] and the inertia forces of the inner ear fluid [16]; (4) compressions and expansions of the cochlear space [16];

Irwansyah et al.: Improved Low-Frequency Crosstalk Cancellation in Bone Conduction
(5) sound pressure transmission from the intracranial content, such as the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) [17]. Fig. 2 illustrates these five pathways by which BC sounds can also reach the inner ear on the opposite side of the head. In practice, however, it is difficult to distinguish between these pathways.
The question now is how to attenuate BC crosstalk being delivered to the other ear; and whether it is possible. Ideally, phase and level information of the vibrational response in the inner ear may be used to attenuate crosstalk by delivering a cancellation sound with a second BT; however, it is difficult to measure. Based on Fig. 2 above, an alternative entity that is easily accessible in live humans—and may be used to cancel crosstalk—is the ECSP in the outer ear. A recent research on the outer ear pathway during BC hearing by Surendran and Stenfelt [13] reported that the contribution from the ECSP is 10 dB below other contributors at frequencies up to 2 kHz and becomes less important at frequencies above 4 kHz. Although the ECSP is not a major contributor, it is still unclear whether canceling crosstalk sounds in the outer ear does not affect other BC pathways. For example, when the ECSP can be reduced by canceling crosstalk, the vibrations of the bony ear canal, part of the temporal bone that produces ECSP, are expected to decrease in amplitude. This may influence Pathways 3 and 4 and thus result in a reduction in the total BC perception because the outer ear and inner ear are relatively close and connected by the same temporal bone. In the case of patients with conductive hearing loss, sounds are unable to travel through the AC pathway due to an obstruction or damage to the outer or middle ear. So, the total perception might depend only on Pathways 3, 4, and 5; see Fig. 2.
In this study, we aim to investigate whether the ECSP can serve as an alternative, easily accessible entity for developing a crosstalk cancellation system to improve the utility of using two BTs. However, one limitation of this present study is that it focused on participants with normal hearing. Conducting this study on patients with conductive hearing loss is necessary to evaluate whether they would actually benefit from the findings presented here, which remains our future work.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text:
Many studies have investigated the binaural benefits of using a pair of bone conduction hearing devices [4]–[10]; however, only a few studies have investigated how to reduce crosstalk using a method called “crosstalk cancellation” [19]–[21]. The method was originally developed to minimize crosstalk between two loudspeakers and two ears to accurately reproduce binaural sounds [22], [23]. Fig. 3 shows the crosstalk issue in binaural sound reproduction over loudspeakers, in principle, similar to that over two BTs. As suggested by Liao, Mcleod, and Culling [20], [24], it is necessary to estimate the transfer functions from each BT to each cochlea [20] or to understand the phase and level of a sound reaching the cochlea from each BT [24] in order to create a crosstalk cancellation system.
Liao investigated the implementation of a crosstalk cancellation system on a dry human skull [20] in which accelerometers mounted at the arcuate eminences were assumed as the cochleae. It was reported that crosstalk cancellation worked well in the frequency range of 0.25–1.5 kHz with an attenuation of up to 12 dB, depending on the frequency. Although we cannot generalize the result due to the difference in properties between a dry human skull and a living human head, a similar cancellation performance might be observed in the same low frequency range; however, a noninvasive method is required to confirm this.
Several attempts have been made to implement a crosstalk cancellation system on the human head [19], [25]. Zhong proposed a method based on psychoacoustic measurements [25]: this method works by canceling a BC pure tone (from one BT) with an AC pure tone (from an earphone). If a participant can feel the silence due to the cancellation of two pure tones,

the phase and level to achieve the silence are collected. The collected phases and levels at different frequencies are then used to predict the new phases and levels required for BC sounds from two BTs to effectively cancel each other out at the cochlea. The method was published as a patent document [25], and there is no detailed information on the extent to which crosstalk can be attenuated. In our previous study, we attempted to achieve crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea by canceling crosstalk at a sensor in the ear canal [19]. Although the crosstalk could be canceled, participants did not experience significant attenuation, which we believe was due to the sensor located at the ear canal entrance and thus too far to the cochlea. In addition, the crosstalk cancellation achieved at the sensor location was also found to be ineffective for frequencies below 800 Hz [19].
A recent and promising method to achieve crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea is the so-called two-BT method developed by Mcleod and Culling [21]. Unlike the method proposed by Zhong [25], the two-BT method does not require earphones and only relies on two BTs, allowing it be used in patients with conductive hearing loss. In the two-BT method, two pure tones from two BTs are presented to the head. Then, a participant is asked to manually adjust the phase and level of one of the tones until the participant perceives the sound moving from the center of the head to the left or right in an imaginary plane, known as lateralization. When the laterality perceptually reaches its extreme, crosstalk cancellation is assumed to be achieved at the cochlea. Subjective evaluations of three participants showed that the method could achieve crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea over a wide frequency range of 1 to 4 kHz with an average benefit of 12.1 dB [21], significantly outperforming previous studies in terms of frequency range. Although, the effectiveness of the method was clearly demonstrated, participants found it difficult to adjust the phase and level at low frequencies [21]; as a result, this method is limited to cancellation at frequencies above 1 kHz. Despite these findings, because localization cues were considered dominant at low frequencies [26], we consider it necessary to further evaluate the extent to which crosstalk cancellation can be achieved at frequencies below 1 kHz.
In this paper, we propose a crosstalk cancellation scheme for two BTs. In contrast to the two-BT method in which the phase and level required for crosstalk cancellation were subjectively set by the user [21], here we developed an objective cancellation method based on the sound pressure produced by the vibrations of the bony ear canal—part of the temporal bone—in response to BC stimulation. It is important to note that the primary contribution of this study was not to develop a new method but rather to investigate an alternative cancellation strategy and adapt existing techniques to the problem of crosstalk. Specifically, our contributions are as follows:
• We implemented a crosstalk cancellation system using two BTs and a probe microphone. In principle, the system measures the sound pressure produced by crosstalk in the ear canal and then adjusts the anti-crosstalk sound from the second BT to negate that sound pressure.
• We investigated whether the sound pressure produced in the ear canal could serve as an alternative entity for implementing crosstalk cancellation. This was achieved by measuring tone reception thresholds (TRTs) at frequencies below 1 kHz under two noise conditions: with and without crosstalk cancellation. To the best of our knowledge, no studies have been reported on the TRT results at low frequencies, except at high frequencies [21].

sections.heading: III. METHODS & EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: With the above in mind, we describe an alternative approach to implement a crosstalk cancellation system using two BTs and a probe microphone. Our approach relies on the change in ear canal sound pressure (ECSP) level in response to BC stimulation to estimate impulse responses (IRs). The IRs are then used estimate the crosstalk compensation (CTC) filter coefficients using the filtered-x least mean square algorithm. Using the CTC filter, an anti-signal can be produced to cancel crosstalk at the probe microphone, as illustrated in Fig. 4(a). The phase and level of the Fourier transform of the filter coefficients are considered the required phase and level, respectively, to achieve crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea only if participants can feel the cancellation.

sections.heading: A. ETHICS
sections.text:
The procedure presented in the current study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Life Science Research of Chiba University. Informed consent was obtained from all participants prior to the experiments.

B. HYPOTHESIS Since the ear canal is close to the cochlea, we hypothesized that when crosstalk cancellation occurs at the probe microphone location, participants may still feel the cancellation. To confirm this hypothesis, we measured tone reception threshold (TRT), the lowest tone level participants could detect under two noise conditions: with and without crosstalk cancellation, as illustrated in Fig. 5. We assume that cancellation occurs at the cochlea if the TRTs with crosstalk cancellation are lower than those without cancellation.
C. PARTICIPANTS The participants were seven young adults (six males and one female) aged between 21 and 31 years (mean = 24.29 years) with no tinnitus. They all had normal pure-tone audiometric thresholds (<25 dB hearing level) at octave frequencies. The amount of earwax in the participants was also confirmed not to cause problems such as blockage when earplugs were inserted deeply into both ear canals. In addition, all participants had prior experience with measurements that relied on their responses to auditory stimuli.
RadioEar B81 BTs mounted on a headband were placed at locations equivalent to the bone-anchored hearing aid, as illustrated in Fig. 4(b). To maintain a good acoustic coupling, the headband was adjusted to achieve a force of 2.5–3.0 N as suggested by Mcleod et al. [24] and Reinfeldt et al. [27]. An ER-10B+ probe microphone from Etymotic was inserted into the left ear canal to estimate an anti-crosstalk signal, as shown in Fig. 4(a). For both TRT measurements, a pair of 3M push-ins earplugs was used to prevent any AC sound radiating from two BTs from entering both ear canals (Fig. 5). All experiments were performed in an anechoic room.
D. EQUIPMENT GNU Octave software was used to create sound stimuli sampled at 16 kHz. Sound generation and recording were performed using ALSA audio controlled with Python on a Linux operating system. A Sound Blaster Omni Surround 5.1 USB sound card was used for digital-to-analog (DA) and analogto-digital (AD) conversions. ECSPs were captured using the Etymotic ER-10B+ low-noise microphone system and amplified by 40 dB.
E. B81 BONE TRANSDUCERS Before starting the experiments, the frequency responses of the two B81 BTs we used in this study were first measured to ensure they had the same response. The measurement set-up used to obtain the B81 frequency response was adopted from Jansson, Frohlich, et al. [28], [29]. The B81 BT was applied to a B&K 4930 artificial mastoid with a static force of 5.4 N, as illustrated in Fig. 6(a). When a test signal at 1VRMS was presented to the B81 BT, the output voltage from the artificial mastoid was amplified using a B&K 2690 amplifier. The final voltage level was then converted to a force level in decibel relative to 1µN. The time-stretched pulse signal [30] was used as the test signal to measure the frequency response.
Figs. 6(a) and (b) show the B81 responses in frequency and time domains, respectively. The frequency response obtained from the measurement was similar to that in the B81 datasheet [31]. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the left and right BTs used in this study produced almost the same responses both in the frequency and time domains. In addition, the level differences between the two responses were less than 1 dB at frequencies between 200 Hz and 5 kHz, meaning that both left and right BTs were almost identical.

sections.heading: F. EXP 1: IMPULSE RESPONSES
sections.text: After confirming that the two BTs used in this study were almost identical, especially at target cancellation frequencies between 0.25 and 1 kHz, we then proceeded to measure impulse responses. Impulse response (IR) is important in our approach because it can be used not only to predict the level of BC crosstalk from the contralateral BT but also to estimate the phase and level required for crosstalk cancellation at the probe microphone. In this study, IR is defined as the impulse response between the B81 BT and the probe microphone, denoted as h{·}(n).

sections.heading: 1) Procedure
sections.text: As previously described in Section IIIC, participants wore a headband with BTs attached to it, as shown in Fig. 4(b). To obtain IRs of each participant, two time-stretched pulse (TSP) signals [30] were presented alternately to the ipsilateral and contralateral BTs. At the same time, the change in ECSPs was recorded by the probe microphone in the participant’s left ear canal. The duration of each presented TSP signal was approximately 2.05 s (or 32,768 samples with a sampling rate of 16 kHz). The IR was obtained from the convolution between the recorded TSP signal and the inverse TSP

Two IRs, hRL(n) and hLL(n) (as illustrated in the top left of Fig. 7), were obtained from a single measurement, and this measurement was repeated seven times. sections.heading: 2) Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the frequency responses from the ipsilateral and contralateral BTs to the probe microphone in seven participants, and was obtained by applying a Fourier transform to their IRs. The frequency axis ranged from 125 Hz to 2 kHz, as shown in the figure above, and was selected to clearly highlight the target cancellation frequencies (i.e., the yellow shaded area between 0.25–1 kHz). The solid line indicates the average of seven measurements, and the shaded band shows the standard deviation.
As expected, we observed consistent frequency response patterns within the same participant—indicated by the narrow shaded area around the solid line—despite small changes in BT position during repeated measurements. While the same BTs were used on each participant, the patterns differed between participants, likely due to differences in participant’s head geometry and mechanical properties. In general, however, the patterns shared a common factor: the red line was almost at the same level as the blue line—and even higher in some participants—indicating the crosstalk was not negligible at frequencies below 1 kHz and may be the main factor that limits the benefits of using a pair of BTs.

sections.heading: G. EXP 2: PHASE AND LEVEL FOR CANCELLATION
sections.text: The second experiment was integrated into the first experiment. During repeated measurements, after the IRs were obtained and before the subsequent measurement was made, the current IRs were used to estimate the phase and level required to achieve crosstalk cancellation via a computer simulation. The details of how the phase and level were estimated and whether cancellation was achieved at the probe microphone in the ear canal are described as follows:

sections.heading: 1) Estimation of Phase & Level
sections.text:
To reduce a crosstalk sound from one BT, an anti-crosstalk sound from the opposite BT must be designed specifically to have the same amplitude but opposite phase relative to the original crosstalk sound. Thus, they can effectively cancel each other out at the sensor location. In this study, we define the required phase and level for achieving crosstalk cancellation at the probe microphone as the phase and level of the fast Fourier transform (FFT) of linear filter coefficients. We define this crosstalk compensation (CTC) filter wRL(n).
To achieve crosstalk cancellation in each user’s ear canal, as illustrated in Fig. 4(a), the filtered-x least mean square (FxLMS) algorithm is used to estimate the optimal CTC filter coefficients based on each user’s IRs. The algorithm works by updating the coefficients to minimize a defined cost function. Since we target crosstalk cancellation at the probe microphone, the cost function is then defined as the signal observed at the probe microphone e(n), given by

sections.heading: 2) Procedure
sections.text:
The second experiment was conducted simultaneously with the first experiment in order to confirm the cancellation performance of the algorithm described earlier. Because it was performed each time the participants removed and replaced the headband, this means it was repeated seven times per participant, as was the first experiment. Once the IRs were estimated, the participants were required to wait for less than one minute as the GNU Octave code began to estimate the phase and level required for crosstalk cancellation. The code then generated a test signal that was presented to the participant’s head with and without an anti-signal.
Table 1 shows the pseudocode used to determine the optimal CTC filter coefficients for cancellation. When the code was executed, the number of coefficients p was set to 512, which corresponds to 32 ms. Because the target cancellation frequency range was between 250 and 1000 Hz, white noise bandpass filtered with cutoff frequencies of 224 and 1122 Hz was used as the input signal, sR(n), to adjust the CTC filter coefficients until e(n) converged.
Finally, a 5-s bandpass filtered white noise sound was prepared as the test signal. We estimated the anti-noise signal by
passing the test signal through the CTC filter obtained when the simulation converged, and found the signal to be approximately 87 mVRMS for all participants. The 5-s band noise and its anti-noise signal were presented to the participant’s head to confirm whether crosstalk cancellation was achieved at the probe microphone. If no cancellation occurred, he/she would be excluded from the third experiment.

A phase unwrapping process was applied to the phase difference to obtain a continuous phase. If the unwrapped phase difference decreases to a negative value while the frequency rises, the anti-signal presented to the ipsilateral BT must be delayed to cancel crosstalk at the probe microphone. If the level difference is positive, the anti-signal presented to the ipsilateral BT will be stronger than the signal sent to the contralateral BT, thus achieving destructive interference. In addition, the positive level difference also means that the frequency response from the ipsilateral BT, hLL(n), is normally at a lower level than the response from the contralateral one, hRL(n); in other words, at a frequency where the level difference is positive (Fig. 9(b)), the blue line is usually below the red line (Fig. 7), and vice versa.
As expected, because the frequency responses (Fig. 7) differed between participants, the patterns of level differences (Fig. 9(b)) were similarly different, albeit less so. Conversely, similar patterns of phase differences (Fig. 9(a)) were observed among all participants at frequencies lower than 630 Hz; once above 630 Hz, phase differences between participants became more varied. We observed the sudden change at frequencies (case (i)) between 800 Hz and 1 kHz for Participant 5 and (case (ii)) between 630 Hz and 800 Hz for Participants 1, 3, 6, and 7, (see Fig. 9(a)). The sudden change in phase difference was frequently followed by a corresponding change in the level difference in the same frequency range, resulting in a reduction of the cancellation performance at the probe microphone, as shown in Fig. 10.

As shown in the spectrum above, most green lines are below the red lines, indicating that crosstalk cancellation occurred at the probe microphone in all participants’ ear canals. Cancellation performance as a function of frequency differed between participants, which was expected because each participant’s head was geometrically and physically unique. Furthermore, in in-
stances, whereby an anti-resonance comes from the ipsilateral BT but not the contralateral BT, crosstalk cancellation performance diminishes. Such a condition was observed in the frequency responses (see Fig. 7) of case (i), resulting in poor cancellation performance (see Fig. 10), and may have been caused by the anti-resonance frequency, resulting in the sudden change in phase difference (Fig. 9(a)) and level difference (Fig. 9(b)) for case (i). In general, we confirmed that crosstalk cancellation occurred in all participants’ ear canals; thus, they were all eligible to proceed to Experiment 3.

sections.heading: H. EXP 3: TONE RECEPTION THRESHOLD (TRT)
sections.text: The objective of the third experiment was to confirm whether crosstalk cancellation designed to occur at the probe microphone could still be felt by participants. In this study, we used tone reception thresholds (TRTs) as subjective indicators to confirm crosstalk cancellation at the cochlea.

sections.heading: 1) Sound Stimuli
sections.text: Fig. 5 illustrates TRT measurements under two noise conditions: with and without crosstalk cancellation. We used onethird octave band noise to mask a pure tone for both conditions. A pure tone was delivered to the ipsilateral (left) BT, while the band noise was delivered to the contralateral (right) BT. For the condition with crosstalk cancellation, an additional anti-noise signal was also presented to the ipsilateral BT. Because we evaluated crosstalk cancellation at low frequencies, one-third octave bands of noise were centered at 250, 315, 400, 500, 630, 800, and 1000 Hz. The band noise was passed to the CTC filter of each participant to estimate a person-specific anti-noise signal. The band noise was presented at a constant level of 40 dB sensation level but the anti-signal’s level depended on individual phase and level difference data (Fig. 9).

sections.heading: 2) Procedure
sections.text:
Immediately after participants completed the second experiment, they were asked to remove the probe microphone and deeply insert a pair of earplugs into the ear canals, as shown in Fig. 5. Then, the CTC filter obtained from the second experiment was used to estimate the anti-noise signal for measuring TRTs. When participants took a break during which the BTs were removed, they were required to repeat a single trial of the first and second experiments to update the CTC filter coefficients to account for positional changes; otherwise, crosstalk cancellation would degrade or fail entirely.
Here TRT was estimated by the 2-down/1-up adaptive twointerval forced-choice procedure [32]. To carry out the procedure, a graphical user interface (GUI) was used to present two intervals sequentially, each containing a 1-s band noise but a 0.6-s pure tone sounding randomly in only one of them. The GUI presented two buttons, one of which turned green when the interval was played (Fig. 11(b)). All participants knew that a pure tone would be presented either by Button 1 or 2. After two intervals were played, participants were asked to choose the interval in which the target pure tone was heard by clicking one of the buttons. We set the starting level of the target pure tone at -15 dB re 1VRMS. If participants managed to give two consecutive correct responses, the pure tone level would be decreased by 4 dB; on the other hand, if one incorrect response was detected, it would be increased by 4 dB. After the first four reversals, 2-dB step was then used (Fig. 11(a)). Each run consisted of 12 reversals, and TRT was calculated by averaging the levels at the last eight reversals. Each participant performed 14 runs of TRT measurements at seven frequencies with and without crosstalk cancellation.

sections.heading: 3) Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 12 shows the tone reception thresholds (TRTs) with and without crosstalk cancellation at seven frequencies in seven
participants. If crosstalk cancellation occurs at the cochlea or the band noise is successfully canceled in the left ear, a participant will detect a pure tone at a lower TRT (green marker) than without crosstalk cancellation (red marker), indicating the addition of an anti-noise signal improves TRT.
As shown in Fig. 12 above, most green markers were lower than the red ones, indicating that crosstalk cancellation benefited all participants, albeit at varying levels relating to their own cancellation performance (Fig. 10) in the second experiment. For example, in the case of Participant 5 at frequencies between 800 and 1000 Hz, when poor cancellation was observed at the probe microphone (see Fig. 10), TRT results also showed that there was almost no difference between thresholds with and without crosstalk cancellation at 800 Hz (see Fig. 12). Conversely, when the probe microphone observed crosstalk cancellation at all target frequencies (see Participants 2 and 4 in Fig. 10), their TRTs with crosstalk cancellation at the same frequencies were also lower than those without crosstalk cancellation (Fig. 12).
In some cases, a noticeable crosstalk cancellation was observed at the probe microphone but TRTs showed opposite results. For example, in the second experiment, the microphone observed crosstalk cancellation at 630 Hz for Participant 1 and at 800 Hz for Participant 3; see Fig. 10. However, their TRT results (in Fig. 12) showed no difference, meaning that they perceived no cancellation. A similar case was also found in Participant 7, where a cancellation of more than 10 dB was observed at the probe microphone at frequencies of 400, 500, and 630 Hz (Fig. 10). However, TRTs with crosstalk cancellation showed only small

improvements at 400 Hz and 500 Hz, and worsened at 630 Hz (see Fig. 12). One possible explanation for these cases might be because crosstalk cancellation was actually designed to occur at the microphone. Thus, depending on the frequency, the amount of destructive interference at the cochlea may have been worse than at the probe microphone.
In general, adding an anti-noise signal improved TRT in all participants, the averages of which are shown in Table 2. The lowest benefit of 6.7 dB was identified at a frequency of 800 Hz, while the greatest benefit presented as 13.4 dB at 500 Hz.
IV. GENERAL DISCUSSION We hypothesized that the proximity of the ear canal to the cochlea would allow participants to perceive a change in the level of crosstalk if crosstalk cancellation occurred at the location of the probe microphone in the ear canal. We investigated this hypothesis by measuring TRTs under two noise conditions: with and without crosstalk cancellation, as presented in Fig. 12. From the figure, we confirmed that participants could indeed perceive the cancellation, indicated by most TRTs with crosstalk cancellation being lower than without cancellation. However, it should be noted that TRT measurements in this study were performed only in participants with normal hearing and not in patients with conductive hearing loss. Because we reduced—or canceled altogether—the ear canal sound pressure (ECSP) level caused by crosstalk, there is a possibility that crosstalk cancellation felt by participants was actually the decrease in the ECSP level, indicating that TRTs may be ECSP-dependent in normal-hearing participants. Further investigation is needed to confirm whether patients with conductive hearing loss would actually benefit from the crosstalk cancellation method presented here.
In order to achieve destructive interference at the probe microphone, the phase and level differences required to create an anti-crosstalk signal were estimated from IRs of each participant using the FxLMS algorithm. Fig. 9 shows the phase (a) and level (b) differences required for crosstalk cancellation in each of the participants. The primary advantage of the method presented here is that the required phase and level can be predicted much faster (less than 1 min) when compared to the two-BT method proposed by Mcleod and Culling that requires approximately 50 mins [21]. Our method, however, produced less accurate estimations because the target cancellation was at the probe microphone and not at the cochlea. As discussed in Subsection IIIH(3), at certain frequencies, three out of seven participants felt no difference or only slight improvements in TRT with the addition of an anti-crosstalk signal, although the microphone in the ear canal showed an attenuation of over 10 dB. One possible solution to this problem is to adopt the two-BT method. The CTC filter coefficients estimated using the FxLMS can be manually tuned in the frequency domain at a specific frequency until participants feel silence or experience a change in laterality due to the cancellation of two tones. This approach may improve our current method and enable cancellation in a wider frequency range, which remains as our future work.
In this study, the FxLMS algorithm was not implemented in real-time. So, the primary and secondary path responses, hRL(n) and hLL(n), were estimated in advance using TSP signals before the FxLMS algorithm was used. In this paper, hRL(n) and hLL(n) refer to the IRs from the contralateral and ipsilateral BTs, respectively, to the probe microphone in the ear canal; see Fig. 8. When BTs were removed and put back in their previous position while maintaining the same static force, hRL(n) and hLL(n) varied only slightly in the frequency domain (see Fig. 7). The estimated primary and secondary paths of each participant were then used to run a simulation where the FxLMS algorithm (Table 1) was used to estimate the coefficients of the CTC filter (see Fig. 9). Our measurements showed that, using the estimated coefficients, crosstalk cancellation was successfully achieved in all participants’ ear canals, indicated by a decrease in ECSP level at low frequencies (see Fig. 10).
There is a certain condition where crosstalk cancellation— a decrease in ECSP level—is difficult to achieve in a specific frequency range but still works fine in the rest of the target low-frequency range. This case was found in Participant 5 at frequencies between 800–1000 Hz (Fig. 10). This occurs when the probe microphone on the ipsilateral side receives much lower sound energy from the ipsilateral BT than from the contralateral BT; which means that the secondary path response hLL(n) has a significantly lower level response of narrow frequency bandwidth than the primary path response hRL(n) (see Participant 5’s IRs at 800–1000 Hz in Fig. 7). This phenomenon is called “anti-resonance” and, according to measurements of BC sound in six cadaver heads, the antiresonance frequency differs between the heads [33]. When the anti-resonance frequency was close to the test frequency, we found no difference in TRTs with and without crosstalk cancellation (see Participant 5’s TRTs at 800 Hz in Fig. 12). Mcleod and Culling also reported that the crosstalk cancellation task becomes difficult if it is near the anti-resonance frequency [34]. In order to achieve the optimal performance, it may be necessary to apply constraints so that the FxLMS algorithm can ignore cancellations near the anti-resonance frequency during the adaptation of the filter coefficients; this also remains future work.

sections.heading: V. DEMO VIDEO
sections.text: A video was created to demonstrate how crosstalk cancellation works and is available at https://youtu.be/1cxV47cxCHQ. Note that the cancellation shown in the video was not implemented in real-time; the anti-noise signal was pre-estimated before recording the video. In a future study, we will focus on the development of a real-time crosstalk cancellation system based on bone conduction.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper demonstrated the feasibility of crosstalk cancellation at frequencies below 1000 Hz. We investigated whether canceling crosstalk sound at a probe microphone in the ear canal could improve tone reception threshold (TRT) with the

IRWANSYAH received the B.Eng & M.Eng in Applied Physics from Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember (ITS) – Indonesia in 2012 and 2013. He completed his Master of Philosophy (M.Phil) & Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in Computer Science at Kumamoto University – Japan in 2016 and 2019. He is currently a postdoctoral research fellow in Nakagawa-Otsuka Lab at Chiba University. His research interests include acoustic signal processing, bone conduction, and binaural hearing.
SHO OTSUKA received the Ph.D. degree in environmental science from the University of Tokyo in 2014. He worked in NTT Communication Science Laboratories as a research associate from 2014 to 2017. He is currently an Assistant Professor of Chiba University. His research focuses on clarification of the mechanism of auditory peripheral processing and its roles in perception, using non-invasive physiological and psychological measurements. He also has been developing
auditory diagnostic tools based on the basic research.
SEIJI NAKAGAWA was born in Fukuoka, Japan in 1971. He received the Ph.D. degree in biomedical engineering and electronic engineering from the University of Tokyo and joined Electrotechnical Laboratory (ETL) as a Research Scientist in 1999. ETL was reorganized into the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) in 2001. He served AIST as a Senior Research Scientist, a Chief Senior Researcher, and a Group Leader in 2006, 2011, and 2015, respec-
tively. Since 2016, he has been a Professor of Chiba University.
Dr. Nakagawa’s research focuses on elucidation of perception mechanisms of humans, especially audition, using various techniques; non-invasive neurophysiological and psychological measurements, and numerical simulations. He is also interested in combining his backgrounds in engineering and auditory science to develop welfare devices like hearing aids and brain machine interfaces, and optimize audio-visual environments. He has published over 170 journal papers and holds more than 40 patents. He is the recipient of the Ogino Award, the Docomo Mobile Science Prize, the Ichimura Award, the Nature medicine-Anges MG Biomedical Award, and the Young Scientists’ Prize at the Commendation for Science and Technology by Japanese government.
